ygData.msgSnippet: ... Yeh AFAIK Ken I use the enable bit in the same way as standard NEAT. Which (off the top of my head) is to disable connections that are replaced when adding

Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Colin, what do you do with the enable bit in your implementation?  
>It's not completely clear what it means to say the enable bit 
>doesn't have an advantage (which may very well be true) since what 
>really matters is how it's being used, i.e. when do links become 
>disabled, and how do they (or do they at all) become reenabled?  Of 
>course, there is a standard way I use them in my version of NEAT, 
>but there are so many ways it could be done and some might actually 
>be better than others.
>ken
>  
>

Yeh AFAIK Ken I use the enable bit in the same way as standard NEAT. 
Which (off the top of my head) is to disable connections that are 
replaced when adding new neurons and then to give them a 25% chance of 
being re-enabled during crossover.

I should stress that the graph is the result of one very short 
experiment in one problem domain, so it is by no means conclusive! On 
the other hand, if the enable bit was significantly beneficial then I 
figured it would have showed up to some degree in the graph 
(http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/enableflaggraph2.png). So based on this 
thinking I have removed all trace of the enable flag from SharpNEAT, at 
least for now, because it makes the pruning phase code a bit easier to 
get my head around - as ever it's never quite as simple as I had expected :)

I also noticed in Derek & Philips Tic-Tac-Toe paper that they mentioned 
that ANJI doesn't use the bit either. SharpNEAT now mimics ANJI in that 
when a new neuron is added, it replaces a connection (as normal) but the 
connection is then deleted altogether.

Colin.
